person:biography.personal-details:content: I am a leading researcher on development economics focusing on the developing economies, specifically South and Southeast Asia, Africa and China. The core concern of my research is to improve understanding of the range of factors influencing economic development in developing economies and to promote their integration into policy and practice. My main analytical approach is the use of econometric methods. I have published 121 peer-reviewed articles in world leading international and national journals, 27 book chapters and several research reports and professional papers in the field of agricultural and applied economics, poverty and livelihoods. I have a significant and sustained international reputation for academic excellence in my field of expertise and the outstanding ‘impact of my research’ is self-evident with h-index of 20 and 1,375+ citations in SCOPUS and h-index of 26 and 3,600+ citations in Google Scholar. I have gained research grants from the Leverhulme Trust, British Academy, DEFRA, DTI, USDA and FAO. Currently, I hold the position of Professor of Economics (non-residential) at Shandong University of Finance and Economics, Jinan, China. Previously, I held the position of Associate Professor/Reader in International Development at the University of Plymouth, UK and Adjunct Professor of Economics at the Faculty of Economics, Chiang Mai University, Thailand. I also held senior research positions at the University of Manchester, UK; International Food Policy Research Institute, Washington, DC, USA; University of Reading, UK, Asian Institute of Technology (AIT), Thailand and BRAC, Dhaka, Bangladesh. I have a substantial track record of PhD supervision and successful completion.
